Effects of Losing Medicaid on Body Weight and Health Behaviors (Job Market Paper)

Approximately 170,000 childless adults abruptly lost Medicaid coverage as a result of Tennessee’s 2005 Medicaid reform. Leveraging this policy-induced variation in health insurance coverage, I investigate the impact of large-scale Medicaid disenrollment on body weight and health behaviors. Using Behavioral Risk Factor Surveillance System (BRFSS) data from 1997 to 2010, I estimate synthetic difference-in-differences models that compare Tennessee’s outcomes before and after the reform with those of a data-driven, synthetic Tennessee. The findings indicate that the reform increased Body Mass Index (BMI) among Tennessean childless adults by 0.37 points, contributing to roughly 4% rise in the prevalence of overweight or obese individuals (BMI≥25). The effects are strong among young (aged 20-39) as well as female childless adults, who likely experienced disproportionately large coverage loss due to the reform. Examining potential mechanisms, I find that decreased participation in moderate physical activity (e.g., cycling, swimming) and dietary changes partially explain the weight gain.

title: Toufiq Rahman
text:
Job Market Paper

  
    Public Health Insurance and Employment Lock: Resolving the TennCare Puzzle
    
      Job Market Paper |
      Draft
      /
      Replication Kit
      /
      Abstract
    

    
      Evaluations of the 2005 TennCare disenrollment yield conflicting estimates, ranging from large employment increases to precise nulls. I show that conflating self-employment with benefits-eligible jobs drives this discrepancy. Analyzing wage employment—the margin relevant for insurance access—I find robust evidence of labor supply expansion, strictly concentrated among the older, less-educated childless adults in Tennessee. The findings demonstrate that the estimated labor supply expansion is not a generalized response to the loss of in-kind transfers, but rather a specific manifestation of employment lock, driven by the interaction of high health risk and binding uninsurability.

title: Toufiq Rahman
text:
Hi, I'm Toufiq.
    I am an applied microeconomist specializing in education, labor, and public economics. My research agenda investigates how public policy design interacts with market frictions to shape human capital and labor market outcomes. I study these dynamics through two lenses: (1) how incentives facilitate human capital accumulation, examining the role of teacher bonuses and educational subsidies; and (2) how safety nets affect labor supply and health capital.

    I am currently a Postdoctoral Researcher at the Johns Hopkins Carey Business School. I received my Ph.D. in Economics from Georgia State University, where I was advised by Professor Daniel Kreisman and worked as a Graduate Research Assistant at Georgia Policy Labs.
